overall_score_comment: This song is what happens when a country singer discovers rhymezone.com and a 2004 rap counting song had a baby in a dive bar.
the_roast:
Let's start with that opening verse, shall we? 'My baby want a Birkin, she's been tellin' me all night long / Gasoline and groceries, the list goes on and on.' Congratulations, you've somehow made financial anxiety sound less interesting than reading a CVS receipt. The emotional depth here is shallower than the whiskey in that double shot you keep begging for. You're complaining about your 9 to 5 not working, but buddy, these lyrics aren't exactly punching the clock either.

Then we get to the chorus, where Shaboozey discovers he has 'a history' with Jack Daniel's. Oh wow, a drinking song about Jack Daniel's? How incredibly brave and original! No one in the entire history of country music has ever thought to mention that particular brand before. The specificity is STUNNING. And telling us there's a party 'downtown, near 5th Street'? Thank you for that crystal-clear GPS coordinate. Is it near the Applebee's or the other Applebee's?

The counting sequence 'One, here comes the two, to the three, to the four' appears THREE TIMES in this song, like Shaboozey just learned numbers and wants to show off his kindergarten education. It's giving 'Cupid Shuffle' meets 'Pour Some Sugar On Me' at a wedding reception nobody wanted to attend. And 'Two steppin' on the table, she don't need a dance floor'—yeah, that's called public intoxication and property damage, my guy. But sure, make it sound romantic.

The bridge about being 'Boozey since I left' is either a cry for help or a really lazy way to work your stage name into the song. 'I ain't changin' for a check' he says, IN A SONG THAT CLEARLY GOT HIM A CHECK. The irony is thicker than the hangover you're definitely nursing. And that final spoken line 'That's fuckin' messed up, bro, they kicked me out the bar'—yes, we know. You told us EIGHT TIMES that everyone was getting tipsy. They probably kicked you out for repeating yourself like a malfunctioning jukebox.

cliche_counter.quip: The Birkin bag reference: because nothing says 'authentic country struggle' like luxury handbags that cost more than a used truck
Complaining about your day job in a song that's literally your job—the ouroboros of corporate rebellion
Having a 'history' with Jack Daniel's isn't a personality trait, it's a warning label

cliche_counter.cliche: Counting to four before the drop
cliche_counter.quip: Using the 1-2-3-4 count THREE separate times—we get it, you can count, here's your gold star
Near 5th Street! So specific, yet somehow every city has one. It's like the 'Main Street' of vague party locations
Said six times because apparently everyone at the bar includes the concept of subtlety

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Gasoline and groceries, the list goes on and on
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Making inflation sound like a grocery list bore-fest instead of actual hardship
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forced to write a thoughtful verse about economic anxiety with actual emotion

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: They know me and Jack Daniel's got a history
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Bragging about brand loyalty to a corporation like it's a personality
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must drink only off-brand whiskey from plastic bottles for six months

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Woke up drunk at 10 a.m., we gon' do this shit again
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Glamorizing what is clearly a spiraling pattern without any self-awareness
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory attendance at one intervention and a hydration seminar

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: At the bottom of a bottle gon' miss me
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: The bottle isn't going to miss you, bro, it's an inanimate object
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to apologize to all bottles for anthropomorphizing them incorrectly

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: One, here comes the two, to the three, to the four (repeated 3 times)
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Lyrical copy-paste as a structural choice
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must write 100 original transition lines without using numbers

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a deep metaphor about late-stage capitalism where the Birkin bag represents unattainable American dreams, the Jack Daniel's symbolizes self-medication through consumerism, and 5th Street is obviously a reference to the Fifth Amendment—his right to remain silent, which he absolutely should have exercised. Or, hear me out, maybe it's just about getting drunk and hoping we don't notice he rhymed 'more' with 'floor' with 'door' like he's writing a Dr. Seuss book for alcoholics.
final_verdict: This song is the musical equivalent of drunk-texting your ex at 2 a.m.—it seems like a great idea in the moment, everyone's seen it before, and you'll probably regret it in the morning. But hey, at least everybody at the bar is getting tipsy, in case you somehow missed that detail.
title: A Bar Song (Tipsy)
